channel.title: A Java 2D Game Engine (JaGE)
channel.description:
Before I start, let me say I don't know jack shit about Java. All I did was downloaded an IDE, fired it up, and set a web page to Google. It was supposed to resemble my C# game engine.
Some things you should know: -Java conventions are nowhere near perfect. I leaned towards C# on some (Although there's some things that break convention rules overall). -Key press doesn't work worth shit. It's why I abandoned this project. Like I said, I don't know anything about Java, so I can't imagine why stuff happened like it did (Although I have an idea. From what I googled, Java GUIs have their own thread, which means I would have had to time things right, which I didn't want to do) -Some things you might find messy. This is because I encountered a series of problems and got too lazy to clean up the experimented code. This includes unneeded imports. -Some of you are gonna get all pissy cause there are some really small classes, but I had later plans for them (Like a scripting engine processor in the EventProcessor class that never got added) and don't feel like explaining them here.
So! This is a small game engine I made in about a day. It has regular and animated objects and some input stuff. You'll find the MapObject class is empty. It was going to be the object for maps that included views and its own objects. It's pretty fast. At an uncontrolled speed, I got over 100 FPS with 101 animated objects on the screen. Here's a screeny of what you'll find.
[img]http://img694.imageshack.us/img694/4515/javafail.png[/img]
Nothin' special, just thought I'd post here. If (Ha, as if I'm talking to anybody) anyone wants to use this, you don't need my permission or to give me credit. This was like a Google puzzle. I was just lucky enough to put the pieces together.
~Lin

item.title: A Java 2D Game Engine (JaGE)
item.dc:creator: @Jython super_
item.description:
@Jython wrote:

note using GetAsyncKeyState means you are a fucktard

Read full topic

item.title: A Java 2D Game Engine (JaGE)
item.dc:creator: @abraham2119 abraham2119
item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

[quote=“Newty, post:13, topic:342239”][quote author=super_ link=topic=438651.msg3283838#msg3283838 date=1280071280]

Good Job. Wonder what i could make out of this.

Edit; wrote a basic compiler for this and i added a L&F JFrame onto the client. looks pretty good i like it

you wrote your OWN java compiler just for this? damn.
[/quote]

He Should Release It Closed Sources On Sun. :mad: :eek: :o :o :)[/quote]Didnt mDog already Do that? o(-.-)o

[quote=“Lin, post:6, topic:342239”][quote author=Fat Cookies link=topic=438651.msg3223719#msg3223719 date=1275388896]
Overall it’s not as bad as you say but there are still some issues.

Your InputHandler isn’t written very well and I don’t understand why you need to keep track of every button pressed (You could have done this in a much simpler manner).
I wouldn’t put a draw method in your GameObject class (which should be called Entity). It would better in your engine class.
You’ve mentioned it yourself but you should really put all the class fields at the top of the class; this makes it so much easier to read.

[/quote]Actually, the InputHandler was to make input checking as simple as possible. Since I planned on making a game out of this, I was going to use code and specific objects. For example, InputHandler.KeyDown(KeyEvent.VK_X) would be all it took to check if X was being held down.[/quote]too used to GetAsyncKeyState, eh

Read full topic

item.title: A Java 2D Game Engine (JaGE)
item.dc:creator: @abraham2119 abraham2119
item.description:
@abraham2119 wrote:

[quote=“cows1471, post:9, topic:342239”]sigh yes, i know what it is the soul, but why do you need to use it?[/quote]In Java, all class functions are by default virtual. In other words, by default it allows a subclass to override it. Because of this, the compiler doesn’t force the override annotation upon you, though it is better practice. The annotation makes the compiler perform validation checks on whether that function is actually overriding a superclass’ function or not. This is useful in case you intended to override a function but mistakenly misspelled its name definition, or something similar.

I for one, have the bad habit of never using these annotations since I don’t expect myself to make a mistake while naming the function, but most Java developers will tell you to err on the side of caution and always implement it, as this also adds for code legibility.

Read full topic

item.dc:creator: @the_soul The Soul
item.description:
@the_soul wrote:

[quote=“cows1471, post:7, topic:342239”]I’ve seen worse, not bad lin - not as bad as you make it out to be.

Why do i keep seeing this though?

@Override[/quote]

That’s the override annotation used to override methods…

item.title: A Java 2D Game Engine (JaGE)
item.dc:creator: @Lin Lin
item.description:
@Lin wrote:

[quote=“Fat Cookies, post:5, topic:342239”]Overall it’s not as bad as you say but there are still some issues.

Your InputHandler isn’t written very well and I don’t understand why you need to keep track of every button pressed (You could have done this in a much simpler manner).
I wouldn’t put a draw method in your GameObject class (which should be called Entity). It would better in your engine class.
You’ve mentioned it yourself but you should really put all the class fields at the top of the class; this makes it so much easier to read.[/quote]Actually, the InputHandler was to make input checking as simple as possible. Since I planned on making a game out of this, I was going to use code and specific objects. For example, InputHandler.KeyDown(KeyEvent.VK_X) would be all it took to check if X was being held down.

Why would the draw method go better in the Engine class? That makes no sense at all. All game objects have something to draw, and different objects would extend it and override the draw method… If you were thinking it would have been easier to give objects a type value and check the value for drawing, that would have been terrible.

Read full topic

item.title: A Java 2D Game Engine (JaGE)
item.dc:creator: @Fat_Cookies Fat Cookies
item.description:
@Fat_Cookies wrote:

Overall it’s not as bad as you say but there are still some issues.

Your InputHandler isn’t written very well and I don’t understand why you need to keep track of every button pressed (You could have done this in a much simpler manner).
I wouldn’t put a draw method in your GameObject class (which should be called Entity). It would better in your engine class.
You’ve mentioned it yourself but you should really put all the class fields at the top of the class; this makes it so much easier to read.

Read full topic
